text: we take a look at the probability of in the money for the 13 days to expiration I'm just using a short put here it's the 4235 and this has a 30.4 percent probability of in the money very very close to this Delta the problem with using Delta as an approximation is that that relationship doesn't hold true over all periods of time and it actually breaks down the further out you go for example looking at a same 30 Delta but now we're 104 days out if I look at probability of in the money it's 33.3 percent it's a 3.3 percent variance which doesn't sound like much but that's 10 percent difference between these two numbers the point being is it's a really common thing to use Delta as approximation for in the money I don't think that's going to break anything necessarily but there is a difference and it's also going to change based on volatility volatility is very low right now so these are actually the closest I've ever seen them in terms of the true probabilities to one another and it also changes the further out of the money and the money you go stuff like that this is not a video about probabilities but I do think it's a fun fact and it's why I like to have Delta and the probability of in the money and the probability of a touch because also common way to use probability of a touch is
